channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Blinken Pursues Regional Tour as Mideast Conflict Deepens
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to ease tensions on a visit to Israel, followed by a meeting with the Saudi crown prince in Riyadh. Israel is pressing on with its military campaigns in Lebanon and Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Why Is Israel Poised to Attack Iran?
item.description: The two countries have been fighting a shadow war for years. But direct attacks are bringing direct reprisals, or at least plans for them.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of a building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, that was hit by Iran’s missile attack this month.

item.title: Deadly ‘Terrorist Attack’ on Turkish Aerospace Company Leaves 5 Dead
item.description: Turkey’s interior minister said it was “most probably” the Kurdistan Worker’s Party that carried out the assault on the sprawling Turkish Aerospace Industries complex near Ankara.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Emergency rescue teams and police officers working outside of Turkish Aerospace Industries near Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Modi-Xi Meeting Could Signal a Thaw Between India and China
item.description: A meeting between the two leaders comes just two days after they settled a tense border dispute in the Himalayas. But experts said their long-term geopolitical rivalry will persist.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Valerie Hopkins and Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobylev/BRICS-Rossia2024.ru, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: From left: Chinese President Xi Jinping, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the BRICS summit.

item.title: Manchester Arena Bombing Survivors Win Lawsuit Against Conspiracy Theorist
item.description: A U.K. court found that a conspiracy theorist who claimed the 2017 bombing at an Ariana Grande concert was a hoax had harassed victims and abused media freedom.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Richard Hall in July, after the trial in a harassment suit brought by Martin Hibbert following the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing.

item.title: U.S. Says North Korean Troops Are in Russia to Aid Fight Against Ukraine
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III called the situation “very, very serious,” though he said that what the soldiers were doing in Russia was “left to be seen.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: For weeks, the Ukrainian and South Korean governments have fueled reports that more than 12,000 North Koreans were training to fight alongside Russian soldiers.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Returns to Court to Testify in Rape Case
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot’s ex-husband, Dominique Pelicot, is accused of inviting strangers to sexually assault her while she was drugged and unconscious. The trial has transformed how France discusses sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisele Pelicot on Wednesday at the criminal court in Avignon, France, where she took the stand in a trial that has gripped the country.

item.title: What Is North Korea’s Role in the Russia-Ukraine War?
item.description: North Korea’s supply of munitions has already been critical to the Russian war effort. Now, its troops appear to be poised to join the fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television news report in Seoul on Monday showing soldiers believed to be from North Korea standing in line to receive supplies in Russia.

item.title: Displaced Gazans Brace for Another Harsh Winter
item.description: After a year of war, at least one million people are facing months in the cold. Some said tents, blankets and warm clothes now qualified as luxuries.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: In a tent camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah, in southern Gaza, in February. Many Gazans have now had to flee more than once.

item.title: Stuffed Into Trucks, 78 Thai Protesters Died. Their Killers Are Still Free.
item.description: Twenty years ago, a massacre in southern Thailand fueled an insurgency that has never stopped. If no one is prosecuted for it by Friday, no one ever will be.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Ryn Jirenuwat and Ulet Ifansasti
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine’s Prosecutor General, Andriy Kostin, Resigns Amid Draft Evasion Scandal
item.description: The prosecutor general stepped down after accusations that hundreds of officials obtained fake disability certificates. There have been no public allegations that he was involved in the scheme.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukraine’s prosecutor general, Andriy Kostin, said in a statement that he was responding to an “obviously immoral situation.”

item.title: A U.S. Farming Giant Gets a Message 11 Stories Tall
item.description: Using natural materials from environmental disasters around the country, a Brazilian activist sends a message to a U.S. farming giant.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel and Victor Moriyama
item.media:description: A building in downtown São Paulo, Brazil, was painted with a 15,000-square-foot mural of an Indigenous leader, Alessandra Korap.

item.title: Trump Accuses U.K. Labour Party of Election Meddling
item.description: Donald Trump’s campaign said Britain’s governing Labour Party had engaged in “blatant foreign interference.” Other British politicians have previously acted in support of Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump on the campaign trail in Miami on Tuesday. In 2019, he called into a British radio show to back the Conservative Party in an election.

item.title: White Blobs Wash Up on Canada’s Beaches, Stumping Everyone
item.description: Over a month after the substance began appearing on the southern shores of Newfoundland, a federal agency is still investigating.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Gustavo Gutiérrez, Father of Liberation Theology, Dies at 96
item.description: Once considered revolutionary, his notion of empathy and advocacy for the poor has become a central tenet of Catholic social teaching.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:description: The Rev. Gustavo Gutiérrez in an undated photo. In his teaching and writings, he asserted that the God of the Jewish and Christian traditions exhibits a preferential commitment to the poor.

item.title: G7 Finalizes $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets
item.description: The economic lifeline is expected to be disbursed by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Janet Yellen, the U.S. Treasury secretary, and Serhiy Marchenko, Ukraine’s finance minister, speaking before signing a joint statement saying that the United States will provide a $20 billion loan to Ukraine using Russia’s sovereign assets, at the Treasury Department in Washington today.

item.title: Rohingya Refugees Are Stranded at Sea for Days as Residents Reject Them
item.description: The refugees, after weeks on a boat, will be able to disembark temporarily in a town in Indonesia, but residents have refused to let them stay.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Rin Hindryati and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Residents of South Aceh, Indonesia, approaching Rohingya refugees stranded on a boat to distribute aid on Wednesday.

item.title: Here Are the Hezbollah Leaders Israel Has Targeted
item.description: Hashem Safieddine, the presumed successor to Hassan Nasrallah, is the latest Hezbollah leader Israel says it has killed.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: 4 Can’t-Miss Towns in an Often Overlooked Corner of Japan
item.description: Kyushu, often passed over by international visitors, is rich in crafts, history and culture. Here are four destinations to consider.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Herring

item.title: Tropical Storm Trami Brings Heavy Flooding to the Philippines
item.description: Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes as parts of the country experienced unprecedented flooding, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Flooding in Naga City, the Philippines, on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Early voting starts in all seven swing states.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Voters lined up to cast their ballots in Stamford, Conn., on Monday.

item.title: Blinken Presses Israel for Truces in Gaza and Lebanon
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state, visiting Israel, said the killing of Hamas’s leader last week could create an opening for peace, and he pushed the Israeli prime minister to allow more aid into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Aaron Boxerman, Hwaida Saad and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A medical dispensary was affected by the blast wave from a deadly airstrike in a densely populated neighborhood near Lebanon’s largest public hospital in southern Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: The UK and Germany Agree on New Defense Pact as Russia Threat Rises
item.description: The two governments said they will coordinate more on defense, with British and German troops conducting joint military exercises on NATO’s eastern border.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Defense Minister Boris Pistorius of Germany and his British counterpart John Healey in Berlin, in July.

item.title: An Australian Woman Trying to Rescue Her Phone Gets Stuck Between Boulders
item.description: And she was upside down.
item.dc:creator: Kate Christobek
item.media:description: An Australian woman found herself stuck upside down, and wedged between two boulders, in an attempt to retrieve her phone.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Casting Doubts on the U.S. Election
item.description: Plus, saving Japan’s most popular rice.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Scott Perry.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Hashem Safieddine, Considered a Successor to Nasrallah
item.description: Hashem Safieddine, a cousin of Hassan Nasrallah, joined Hezbollah soon after the group was formed and rose quickly in its ranks.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Hashem Safieddine at a Hezbollah commander’s funeral in Beirut, Lebanon, in June.

item.title: Yehuda Bauer, 98, Scholar Who Saw Jewish Resistance in Holocaust, Dies
item.description: A leading historian of antisemitism, he countered the prevailing narrative of Jewish victimhood and later pushed back against efforts to diminish the Holocaust’s significance.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Yehuda Bauer, an Israeli scholar, reached audiences beyond his fellow academics with a nuanced reading of the Holocaust as a historical event.

item.title: Despite Global Crises, Gas Prices Slide as U.S. Election Nears
item.description: Fuel prices, which had soared after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have dropped to their lowest level since February.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: Prices at the pump averaged $3.16 nationally on Tuesday, down 11 percent from this time last year.

item.title: U.S. to Give Ukraine Millions to Build More Long-Range Drones
item.description: The move, confirmed by a Pentagon official, is in line with a U.S. policy change aimed at shoring up Ukraine’s ability to fight the war against Russia with its own weapons.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Maria Varenikova and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Servicemen of the 5th Separate Kyiv Assault Brigade load drones onto a truck in downtown Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Seven People Planned to Carry Out Assassinations in Israel on Behalf of Iran
item.description: The suspects planned to assassinate two people, a senior Israeli scientist and the mayor of a large Israeli city, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Arab neighborhood of Beit Safafa, which straddles the boundary with the West Bank, in 2022.

item.title: Russian Disinformation Efforts, Including Faked Walz Video, Could Continue After Nov. 5, Officials Say
item.description: Foreign powers including Russia and Iran could move quickly right after the vote to undermine the democratic process, intelligence agencies warn.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Voters at a polling location on Monday in Las Vegas, where early voting has started. Russia, along with Iran and China, has already sought to influence the U.S. election by spreading disinformation.

item.title: Vatican and China Extend Agreement on Catholic Bishops
item.description: Critics argue the pact legitimizes China’s control over church affairs, while defenders say it helps support Catholics faithful to the Vatican in the Communist country.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Vatican said that it remained dedicated to a “respectful and constructive dialogue” to further develop bilateral relations “for the benefit of the Catholic Church in China and the Chinese people as a whole.”

item.title: Putin Welcomes Xi and Other World Leaders to Russia for BRICS Summit
item.description: The Russian leader wants to cast himself as a global statesman, even as the U.S. and its Western allies try to isolate him.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and David Pierson
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with President Xi Jinping in Kazan, Russia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Son of Singapore’s First Prime Minister Says He Is Granted Asylum in the U.K.
item.description: Lee Hsien Yang accused his brother, a former prime minister, of persecuting him politically, inflaming the feud in Singapore’s first family.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Lee Hsien Yang in Singapore in 2020.

item.title: After Israel’s Strike at a Hospital Near Beirut, Search Teams Comb the Ruin
item.description: As search teams combed the ruins of residential buildings across from Rafik Hariri University Hospital just south of Lebanon’s capital, locals listened for signs of their loved ones in the wreckage.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad, Euan Ward and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:description: The wreckage of residential buildings after the deadly strike near Rafik Hariri University Hospital, near Beirut, on Tuesday.

item.title: FBI Is Investigating a Leak That Appears to Show Israel's Plan to Attack Iran
item.description: The documents began circulating on Friday on the Telegram app, and U.S. officials are looking for the original source of the leak.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis taking cover near Kfar Saba, Israel, on Oct. 1, during air-raid sirens warning of incoming missiles fired from Iran.

item.title: I.M.F. Says Inflation Fight Is Largely Over but Warns of New Threats
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said protectionism and new trade wars could weigh on growth.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: I.M.F. Chief Economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas speaking at the I.M.F.-World Bank meetings in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Samuel Alito and Princess Gloria Bonded Over Catholicism and Ending Abortion
item.description: Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis bonded with Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. over Catholicism and ending abortion. She introduced him to her sumptuous world when he visited her Bavarian palace.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle, Philip Kaleta and Ingmar Nolting
item.category: Gloria, Princess of Thurn and Taxis
item.media:description: Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis, a 1980s party girl, has evolved into a conservative Catholic with ties to the European far right.

item.title: India and China Reach Border Deal That Could Ease Tension
item.description: Four years ago, several soldiers from both sides were killed in a bloody melee. Any thaw between the countries could have global implications.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Hari Kumar and Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The Indian prime minister, Narendra Modi, with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at a BRICS summit in Goa, India, in 2016.

item.title: Hamas’s Guerrilla Tactics in North Gaza Make It Hard to Defeat
item.description: Israel has decimated Hamas’s military wing, along with much of Gaza. But the group’s small-scale, hit-and-run approach poses a threat in the enclave’s north.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers carry the coffin of Col. Ehsan Daksa, who was killed in northern Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. and Europe Agree to Finalize $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said an agreement was close. She also rebuked China’s lending practices and called for more debt relief.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said that China needed to help countries that had borrowed money from Beijing to restructure their debts.

item.title: Russia’s Warming Arctic Is a Climate Threat. War Has Shut Scientists Out of It.
item.description: Climate science has been stymied as Russia continues its war in Ukraine. The stalled work threatens to leave the West without a clear picture of how fast the Earth is heating up.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Judah

item.title: Why Sara Duterte Talked About Beheading Ferdinand Marcos Jr.
item.description: The alliance between Sara Duterte and President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr., which brought two notorious dynasties together, has unraveled in spectacular fashion.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. with Sara Duterte at his presidential inauguration in June 2022. They promised national unity when they were elected president and vice president.

item.title: What Life Looks Like for Israelis Living Near Lebanon’s Border
item.description: Homes in northern Israel along the Lebanon border have been under the constant threat of Hezbollah’s rocket attacks since October of last year. We look at life on the ground for the few Israelis who stayed behind.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena and Gabby Sobelman

item.title: China Turns Up the Heat on Taiwan With Live-Fire Drills
item.description: The drills were the latest show of force by China, which claims Taiwan as its territory and has protested Western support for the island.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: The live-fire drills were slated for a week after China encircled Taiwan to demonstrate its potential to choke Taiwan’s access to food and fuel.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Two weeks to the U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times; Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are hunting for the few undecided voters left.

item.title: Coup Attempt by Gulen Allies Led Erdogan to Crack Down in Turkey
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Fethullah Gulen, the powerful preacher who died this week, began as allies. But their falling out brought bloodshed and an Erdogan crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign poster for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Kayseri, Turkey, last year.

item.title: A Radical Approach to Flooding in the UK: Give Land Back to the Sea
item.description: When a huge tract of land on the Somerset coast was deliberately flooded, the project was slammed as “ridiculous” by a local lawmaker. But the results have been transformative.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Four Years in Jail Without Trial: The Price of Dissent in Modi’s India
item.description: A Muslim protest leader has become a symbol of a wide-ranging clampdown on opponents of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Biplov Bhuyan/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The activist Umar Khalid, center, protesting in New Delhi in early 2020. He was arrested later that year.

item.title: What to Know About the BRICS Summit and the Countries Involved
item.description: The group, which seeks to rebalance the global order away from the West, will meet on Tuesday. Here’s a primer.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Leaders from Brazil, China, South Africa, India and Russia at the BRICS Summit in Johannesburg in 2023.

item.title: What Is U.N. Resolution 1701?
item.description: U.N. Security Council Resolution 1701 was intended to create a buffer zone between Israel and Hezbollah. Here’s a look at why it didn’t and what lies ahead in efforts to end the conflict in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Explosions from the fighting between Hezbollah and Israeli forces, as seen from Tyre, in southern Lebanon, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Tries to End War in Lebanon That Biden Envoy Calls ‘Out of Control’
item.description: Israel and Hezbollah say they will keep up attacks in an escalating conflict that has devastated Gaza, is causing misery in Lebanon and could draw Iran deeper into the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike that targeted the village of Khiam in southern Lebanon on Monday.

item.title: Israel Apologizes After Strike Kills 3 Lebanese Soldiers
item.description: The deaths showed the complexity of Israel’s fight with Hezbollah: Lebanon’s army is not a party to the conflict, but it is taking place in its territory.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Cuba Faces Hurricane Oscar After Nationwide Blackout. How Much Can the Island Endure?
item.description: The repeated failure of the power grid and a hurricane that has swamped the island’s eastern end has many Cubans fed up, posing a challenge to the Communist government.
item.dc:creator: Ed Augustin and Frances Robles
item.media:description: A floating power plant in Havana Harbor on Monday. Such plants have become a vital source of power.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Two Weeks Until Election Day
item.description: Plus, Aleksei Navalny’s memoir.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times, Nicole Craine for The New York Times

item.title: Paul Di’Anno, Early Iron Maiden Frontman, Dies at 66
item.description: He sang with the band in its early years before being replaced by Bruce Dickinson. He later worked with other bands and pursued a solo career.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Paul Di’Anno in 1981. He gained popularity on the heavy metal scene in the late 1970s after he became the lead singer of Iron Maiden.

item.title: What Is Al-Qard al-Hasan, the Hezbollah-Linked Finance Group Targeted by Israel?
item.description: The de facto bank is the largest microcredit organization in a country where the traditional banking sector is in shambles.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.media:description: Al-Qard al-Hassan documents scattered at the southern outskirts of Beirut on Monday after Israeli airstrikes.

item.title: Israel Dismantles Iranian Spy Network and Arrests Seven People, Authorities Say
item.description: The suspects, all Israeli citizens, conducted intelligence missions for two years under the direction of two Iranian agents, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Planet Labs showing the air base of Nevatim, in the Negev desert, after Iran’s attack this month.

item.title: Paul Whelan’s Life in a Russian Prison Awaiting a Hostage Swap
item.description: The former U.S. Marine describes the moment of his arrest and the long years waiting for his release.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Paul Whelan, 54, who returned to American soil as part of a historic prisoner swap with Russia, in Washington, on Friday.
